body:
Whilst debugging luvit/luv#742 I noticed we have some slightly duplicated logic with luv's [loop_gc](https://github.com/luvit/luv/blob/master/src/luv.c#L844-L861) function.

I refactored our code so it makes slightly more sense by unwinding the while loop.

comment_data.body:
Now the code is written this way, I'm not sure what this line is really doing. How is it tickling the close callbacks?

@justinmk
It's running the loop, why wouldn't it run pending callbacks? (Maybe I missed a detail in the libuv docs)

> Did you mean just to run the loop once to execute any pending callbacks which _may_ be close callbacks? 

yep

> If so, why wouldn't the `uv_run` call below also do this?

It would, but that may not be reached, depending on `wait`.

Would need to study the git logs to be extra sure. This logic is very tricky, driven by various bug reports.

> For context luv doesn't do this so just trying to understand the differences. For reference luv just does:

luv doesn't care about hangs, whereas we need to exit quickly.

why remove the `UV_EBUSY` check? that seems like a logic change, not just a refactor. should be separate.

if it's not a logic change, the explicitness of `UV_EBUSY` seems beneficial...

```suggestion
  if ((uv_loop_close(loop) != UV_EBUSY) || !wait) {
```

> If our code is _better_ than theirs, then I'd be happy to port some of it over. We use their loop handling for our Lua threads.

It's arguably a logic bug in our system. In theory we should never "hang", but:

- there are (or were) cases where we run `UV_RUN_DEFAULT` and there's nothing on the loop, so we hang forever.
- in other cases, on exit, users simply don't want to wait for plugins/jobs (slow child processes) to cleanup.

> I'd be happy to port some of it over. We use their loop handling for our Lua threads.

It would be a nice feature if they had a flag/param that allows us to opt-in to similar behavior for luv. Probably should be opt-in though; not all callers will want this.
I can't say for sure if this works for all cases. Would need to study the git logs and the linked issues therein.

This function currently only returns 0 of UV_EBUSY so it is functionally equivalent. If a new error return value is added in the future then our current code will just break and return prematurely. The goal of this code is to keep running uv_loop_close until it is successful.
From my search there's like 2 or 3 issues with not a lot of explanation or tests.

> The goal of this code is to keep running uv_loop_close until it is successful.

Are you sure? This part is intended to return quickly, that's why it checks `!wait`. If some other state besides "busy" is introduced, it could make sense to return early then also.
This diff is outdated so probably not much benefit in continuing this. I'm mostly concerned about the wait scenario anyway. The new diff returns early just on `!wait`.
but the new diff does not check the result of `uv_loop_close`, in the case of `wait`. so that is a logic change.
I think the only difference now is that in the case of `wait`, we no longer run `uv_run(loop, UV_RUN_NOWAIT)` at the beginning.
